content: I thought homeschooling was a bad idea; this is even worse. The only reason to skip college is to avoid the backbreaking expenses and lifetime loans. To suggest that one doesn’t actually learn anything in college is simply ridiculous. What makes you think creativity, networking, self-reinvention — to name a few of your own “classes” — aren’t fostered in college? Many people make future business partners and longterm connections with others they met and found common ground with in college. While we’re talking about networking, you do realize that Facebook started as a means for college students to stay connected, right? College campuses tend to be breeding grounds (to follow your “idea sex” point) for transformative ideas. And how can you decide to master a field without knowing what else exists out there? Taking different courses can be a great way to introduce yourself to discover which concepts “set a fire in your heart” or whatever. If your motives are purely to cut costs on your children’s education, you are completely justified, but you must own that. Don’t blow off a whole institution while offering paltry alternatives. Your daughter is right to take her time to think about your offer. I suspect from reading your proposed course outline that what you’re actually trying to achieve is more control over her education. (For example: “Watch a movie every day and discuss” it with you? Really? Why shouldn’t she be able to go do the same thing with people her own age, as college students are wont to do?) She probably doesn’t need you to decide what’s best for her, education-wise, anymore.
